column1: Postal codes in the People's Republic of China (simplified Chinese: 邮政编码（邮编）; traditional Chinese: 郵政編碼（郵編）; pinyin: yóuzhèng biānmǎ (yóubiān)) are postal codes used by China Post for the delivery of letters and goods within mainland China.
China Post uses a six-digit all-numerical system with four tiers: the first tier
column2: composed of the first two digits
column5: or autonomous region; the second tier
column7: shows the postal zone within the province
column8: municipality or autonomous region; the fourth digit serves as the third tier
column9: which shows the postal office within prefectures or prefecture-level cities; the last two digits are the fourth tier
column10: which indicates the specific mailing area for delivery.

column1: The Republic of China (commonly known as Taiwan)
column3: is not under control of the People's Republic of China. Therefore
column4: even though it was assigned official postal codes by China Post
column5: those codes are not in use. ROC's postal bureau
column7: uses a different postal code system. All mails between the PRC and the ROC are treated also as international mails
column8: and mailing to Taiwan from Mainland China actually requires the use of the postal codes set forth by Chunghwa Post. The range 000000–009999 is not in use
column9: because it was originally marked for Taiwan.

column1: Codes starting from 999 are the internal codes used by China Post for handling international (including the SARs and Taiwan) mails
column2: and not used by the general public.
